nasajpl1969105415825666134.content: As @NASA prepares to send human explorers to the Moon and beyond, we are advancing the technology that will enable high-definition video and science data to be transferred... with lasers! More on the Deep Space Optical Communications experiment (DSOC): dir="ltr" href="https://t.co/I9hDUrXeB4" rel="noopener noreferrer nofollow" target="_blank" role="link" style="color: rgb(29, 155, 240);">go.nasa.gov/4ppAPGZ
nasajpl1969105415825666134.author: nasajpl

nasajpl1956501758857105596.content: Those swirls? They’re storms on Jupiter – and some are larger than Earth! This enhanced color view of Jupiter’s south pole was created by a citizen scientist using raw data from the Juno spacecraft's JunoCam.
nasajpl1956501758857105596.author: nasajpl

nasajpl1950514474764685691.content: How will NISAR support agriculture and farming? Hear from the scientists and end users how its data will be used to map crop growth, track plant health, and monitor soil moisture.
nasajpl1950514474764685691.author: nasajpl

nasajpl1947312588083306918.content: Launch date secured! @NASA and @isro are targeting no earlier than July 30 for the launch of NISAR, a powerful new mission to observe Earth's changing surfaces. Learn more dir="ltr" href="https://t.co/QmoALbz3bE" rel="noopener noreferrer nofollow" target="_blank" role="link" style="color: rgb(29, 155, 240);">science.nasa.gov/blogs/nisar
nasajpl1947312588083306918.author: nasajpl

nasajpl1940557360218755402.content: There's a new interstellar comet in the neighborhood! Known as 3I/ATLAS, this comet poses no threat to Earth – but it does provide a rare opportunity to study an object that originated outside of our solar system: dir="ltr" href="https://t.co/7ihCiHi91t" rel="noopener noreferrer nofollow" target="_blank" role="link" style="color: rgb(29, 155, 240);">science.nasa.gov/blogs/planetar
nasajpl1940557360218755402.author: nasajpl

nasajpl1841571229670768716.content: Earth has a temporary, tiny companion. While not quite a "mini moon," since it will never be captured by Earth's gravity, Asteroid 2024 PT5 does have a similar orbit as our planet and will linger in our vicinity for a few months. dir="ltr" href="https://t.co/5fB0Mvf6nq" rel="noopener noreferrer nofollow" target="_blank" role="link" style="color: rgb(29, 155, 240);">go.nasa.gov/3BtIjV2
